thread.section_title: Business News, Economy, Finance & ASX Market News
thread.title: Bendigo Bank full-year cash profit climbs 13pc to $432.4m
thread.title_full: Bendigo Bank full-year cash profit climbs 13pc to $432.4m

author: Shaun Drummond
title: Bendigo Bank full-year cash profit climbs 13pc to $432.4m
text:
Bendigo and Adelaide Bank's annual results were expected to benefit from further house price rises Photo: supplied
Bendigo and Adelaide Bank has just beat consensus forecasts with a cash profit for 2015 of $432.4 million, up 13 per cent on the previous financial year, helped by another big jump in income from its unique Homesafe product.
Statutory profit came in at $424 million, up 14 per cent, with income from operations totalling $1.55 billion, up 7.4 per cent.
The bank will pay a final dividend of 33c per share on September 30. Total dividends for the year are 66c per share.
The bank's net interest margin rose 1.6 percentage points to 1.89 per cent. Costs compared with earnings also rose marginally, with cost-to-income ratio up 0.7 of a percentage point to 55.2 per cent for the year.
Advertisement As expected, Bendigo's Homesafe product was a big contributor to earnings outside interest income. It added more than $63 million to revenue, up 26 per cent on its contribution in 2014.
Homesafe allows the bank to help a home buyer pay for a house by taking a discounted part share in it. Bendigo gets income from the sale of the house and so earnings from this product rise when house prices rise.
The bank has said in the past the contribution from Homesafe will likely fall to about $20 million a year when the present run of sharp house price rises is over.
Analysts will be looking for an update on Bendigo's attempts to achieve Basel Advanced Accreditation, which will allow the bank to hold less capital against its home loans in the same way the Big Four do, at its results briefing today.
They will also be looking for an update on the collection of outstanding loans in the bank's controversial Great Southern agribusiness portfolio as well as the impact of recent repricing of investor loans by major banks.
More to come
